reviewText: Overall, I would recommend picking the game up. There are many levels and game modes, there's a lot to experience. I'm personally not in favor of the third person view, I would much prefer this game be first person. I've also found the hit detection to be a bit wonky and it's also hard to tell what's killing you sometimes due to gunshots not being audible from even remotely far away. The distance which gunshots shouldn't be heard should be much greater than what it currently is.\n\nI wouldn't recommend this game if it weren't for the developers appearing to care about the game and patching it. If they stop patching it/improving it, I'll likely switch this review to not recommended seeing as there were a few other quirks I had with the game as well, such as the server browser. It's not very friendly to the eyes - it would be nicer if you could see an overview or image of the map the servers are currently on next to the name. It would take up more space, but it'd be much more pleasant to view. It would also be nice if they hid empty servers from the list and simply had a check box available for anyone who is actually searching for an empty server.

reviewText:
Greetings fellow gamers! This is Gamer Guy (In a Suit) from the Echo Army YouTube channel! Today I am bringing you a review of The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare. The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare is a Team-Based Multiplayer, Third-Person Shooter that was released on Steam December 8th, 2015 by Publisher/Developer Virtual Basement LLC and Developer Code Headquarters LLC.


(NOTE: This game was reviewed using a key provided by the Developer and/or Publisher)


Video Review:

https://youtu.be/hTm3exFmFNU

The Too Long
date:
Didn't Watch" Review:

Fun little multiplayer shooter. Solid graphics and awesome sound. Just needs the community to grow!
3.5/5 Pick it up for that $10 it's at now or you'll regret it later.

The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare is very much like the old Army Men game series

column19: aside from just the basic "kill the other team" approach. For example

column22: but with some really fun twists. A lot of the players I played with were into the nostalgia kick
column23: as this game does call back to that Army Men series. I think as newer players pick this up
column24: it's community will grow and make this a keeper. On release day
column25: even with the frustration of waiting to get into games and finding enough people
column26: I have enjoyed it enough to give a 3.5/5 as the graphics
column27: sound and gameplay certainly warrant that and it just needs it's community to grow some to be able to stand out some more.\n\nHappy Gaming!!!"

reviewText: It's one of those games I can't either recommend or stay away from Despite its problems it's a colorful and fun third person shooter. You have a game with map design that is unique but at the same time unbalanced for example there's one map that takes place on a train, tan team spawns in at one end & green team spawns in at the other, the objective is to capture & hold 3 cookies, they can be captured in any order, but if you manage to get to the opposite side of the train where the other team spawn, you can just camp the hell out of them and it's nearly impossible to fight back. Theres also a fair amount of exploits in the game as well such as going through walls, hiding in shallow water makes you almost invincible etc. The player base is low which is a shame, it's mostly to do with the lack of content & lack of progression (IMO) newer generation of gamers would rather work towards level ups and unlockables as it gives them a reason to keep playing. It doesn't make it a bad game though when people do come on it's quite enjoyable, even more so when it's a skilled based map and not a camp fest.

reviewText:
I bought it for $10 on sale and it was a great pick-up. I'm not a huge fan of 3rd person shooters but gave this a chance because of the price. Money well spent.

Pros
Graphics are much better than anticipated.
Runs smooth. (I also haven't experienced any bugs myself)
Childhood nostalgia.
Each map is unique.

Cons
Devs should consider a class/customization system. (Right now you spawn with all weapons)
Servers could use some work but not terrible.
Respawn timers should be longer. (Right now it's hard to get a jump on your opponent because of how quickly they respawn)

reviewText: My buddy found this game yesterday and I have to say I don't regret buying it one bit.. The biggest thing that attracted me to it were the maps.. You are literally a little toy infantry soldier in kitchens, bedrooms, fish tanks etc.. The environments are amazing.. If anyone remembers the old unreal tourny maps or cs kitchen maps were you felt like a little inch man running around in rooms, that's exactly what this reminded me of! I've played 3 maps so far and to give you an idea of objectives you have to melt the ice in the freezer to unleasah your toy trex (freezer), push the cup off of the end of the counter before your enemy tips yours off all while running through a lit oven and bubbly dish full sink (kitchen), scoring goals on a foosball table while shooting the crap out of eachother with pigstyle figure moving back and forth on the foosball handle/rods(barnyard foosball can't remember the name lol).. The gameplay and optimisation is great.. I just hope to see some more weapon varieties/overall gameplay/progression updates in the future.. Well worth the $10, I would even pay $15 or more to be honest.. Just helping fund the developers is enough for me to get involved.. I hope it grows greatly! Def pick this up you won't be dissapointed!

reviewText:
Virtual Basement’s (Ark- Survival Evolved) latest game, The Mean Greens, does what a number of bigger games fail to do. While it may sound like some kind of Vegan juice drink, The Mean Greens is charming title that showcases vast amount of potential from a young developer.

The core concept is the classic battle between Green and Tan toy soldiers. Those little pieces of plastic, vaguely human shaped, that has entertained generation after generation. In this case, we’re no longer using imagination to act our play wars, we’re directly playing. From the outside, The Mean Greens looks like a cookie cutter third person shooter, and that’s partly right. The true star of show is not the gameplay, but the maps.



The Mean Greens is about as accessible as you can get. Simple third person shooting, no classes or perks. Variation comes in the form of different weapon types, allowing players to engage from what ever range they wish. It all works well, even if it can lead to some slight sense of repetition creeping in.

Virtual Basement have a clear vision of what they waned to The Mean Greens to be. Map design and concepts reflect the exact vision and themes that were desired. Each map is set in various parts of a typical house. Kitchens, table tops, bath rooms and even the fish tank. It’s nice little throwback to all the typical places we’d wage plastic warfare as children.



Each map has it’s own unique objective, from the classic to the crazy. Be it Free-for-all deathmatch or capture the flag, The Mean Greens puts a twist on it. The most notably of twists comes in the shape of the bubble bath battle for flags. Players are tasked with collecting flags dotted around a bath tub full of floating rubber duckies, with a giant octopus occupying the centre of the tub.

There’s also a play on foosball table in which players battle to push the ball into the opposition goal. Each and every map oozes with character and charm. It’s the little touches that go along way. From the popping of bubbles in the sink, to the haunting yet oddly catchy rendition of Operation Birthday’s ‘Birthday Cake’ song, it’s hard no to smirk when playing.



Presentation forms a key part of the experience. In order to get that true feel of playing with toy soldiers, the visuals have to be on point. It’s a testament to the craftsmanship and care shown by Virtual Basement that the game looks beautiful. The soldiers look amazing, almost to the point you swear you could pick them out of the screen. Environments blend real life elements and colour pallets similar to films like Toy Story, resulting in some brilliant imagery. Each maps has it’s own distinct look, feeding into the concept that this is what you used to think of when you were a child, army men in hand.

The Mean Greens only real issues come in the shape or some sever connection issues and the odd bit of balancing. Within a period of 4 hours, a number of disconnections from sever occurred once the match had ended. This issue was mentioned a few times in the in-game chat, suggesting it’s far from isolated cases. A minor niggle comes in the shape of hit detection and satisfaction. There’s times in which weapons feel like they should be hitting the target. Headshots tend to feel part luck more than skill. It gives the gunplay a touch of being rather floaty instead of satisfying.


Weapon balancing could use some work. One of the six weapons, the bazooka, is hugely overused by nearly every player in the game. The overuse of the weapon results in a number of modes becoming nothing but bazookafest, rendering other weapons slightly pointless. Additional weapons may be on cool down, but the regularity of death and respawns means you’ll be a victim of a rocket extra 30 seconds.

As a whole package, The Mean Greens is an admirable release. With 10 modes, 10 maps, 6 weapons and voice chat, it puts EA’s Star Wars: Battlefront to shame. Code Virtual Basement can be proud of what they’ve produced. It may not be packing all the fancy tricks and frills of other multiplayer titles, but it sure is packed with charm and sheer enjoyment. For less than £12, it’s hard not to recommend The Mean Greens, even more so as a nifty Steam stocking filler for Christmas.

reviewText:
Virtual Basement is just another game-development company to look out for in the future. Their first release, 'The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare' absolutely shows alot of potential, and makes me hungry for more. Powered by the fantastic Unreal Engine, they have created a game that combines warfare with elements that takes us back to our childhood. The characters in the game reminds me of the soldiers from the 'Toy Story' franchise, which was my favourite back in the early days. There is one common opinion I have heard from other people that have played this game: that it gives us a nostalgic flashback from either a game or movie from our childhood.

The online gamemodes are fun and innovative. Melting down a wall of ice before the other team, pushing down a cup from the table before the other team, playing football and many other innovative gamemodes you never thought could fit into a competetive shooter. My favourite one is where both teams spawns on each of their side of a bathtub, where the object is to capture a flag located on a floating boat toy in the enemy's territory and bring it back to the spawn. A challenging capture-the-flag with a twist. There is also a CTF map under water! Besides from the modes that may be confusing when playing first time, they have also included traditional modes such as TDM, FFA & domination.

The gameplay mechanics are also great. You spawn with all weapons, which are made for different kinds of situations. A traditional AK for spraying down your enemys, shotgun for close combats, an RPG that is overpowered, a sniper for long-range attacks and a flamethrower that works great for melting down ice, but not killing. These are all pretty well-balanced. Key for this is the cooldown you get after using an RPG, which would make the game broken if you could use it  at all times. The game does not have that many players (yet), so if you have friends to play it with, it would make the game more enjoyable if you don't want to spend some extra time to find a good server.

The game is constantly being updated, and the developers are active when it comes to interacting and reviewing feedback from the community. This seems to be the start of something good, so I look forward to see what more Virtual Basement may be cooking up for us in the future!

reviewText:
Pros
-Awesome sound track
-Fun to play with people you know due to small match sizes
-Level design is great and there are interesting game modes other than CTF and deathmatch

Cons
-Poorly optimized engine, I had lots of FPS drops and spikes
-Little variety in weapons
-You can play every map the game has in less than 2 hours, so there's not a ton of replayability
-Flamethrower is worse than a pile of flaming garbage.

I played for about an hour and a half with a friend of mine and I decided to get a refund.  It's an interesting concept and the core game is ok, but it's not engaging enough to make me want to come back to it after an hour and a half.

reviewText:
This game has a huge amount of potential, and as many have said in the review section, the ground work is there. Unfortunately, this game has one glaring issue. You see those 0.5 hours of playtime there? Yeah. 0.4 was spent TRYING TO FIND A F***ING GAME. I understand the game isn't being published by those big AAA companies but it is inexcusable to have your game launch and have it take 30 minutes to find one game. Oh, but it doesn't stop there. Once I got into a game, crash. I tried again, crash again. 3rd time is a charm, as I finally got into a game. I think I should start with the pros of this game.
*Pros*
-Amazing atmosphere and level design. The levels all feel unique and are perfectly catered to their respected game mode. The levels give off, to me at least, a V20 Blockland vibe.
-OST is perfect. The 30 minutes I waited to get into a game was both frustrating and uplifting. Why? The OST is so damn catchy. The OST fits every level and moment perfectly and keeps you pumped up while you're playing the game as opposed to how other FPS games have no background music (I'm looking at you Battlefront).
-Combat Rolling is wonderful. Combat rolling in games like Battlefront 2 was very fun and unique because not many games at the time had mechanics like it. It forced people to make new strategies and adapt to a new gameplay style. This carries over perfectly with Plastic Warfare.

*Cons*
-Weapon Balance needs reworking. Everyone has the same equipment at all times. While this means the game is more fair in a sense, from what I've played, everyone just ends up using the Rocket Launcher and Sniper. I think this could be improved by adding in a class system or having some weapons be map pick ups, sort of like Halo.
-No Single Player mode. I can't believe I'm saying this, but even EA's Battlefront has a better single player. Why? Because there is no single player in this game. Having an offline mode with bots would greatly benefit the game, as it would not only help new people become adapted to the gameplay, but it would also make the game more playable, especially with the...
-God Awful Connection. I was able to get into 1 game, 1 f***ing game. I would either..
A. Lose connection to the host (even when I was the host)
B. Server would be full (even if it was 7/10 on the browser menu)
c. Join a game, but crash.
-Movement =/= Control set up. The sprint is extremely fast, so it would make sense that sprint jumping would be effective. Unfortunately, there is a 1-2 second delay in jumping and sprinting, which means you end up stopping and jumping or not jumping at all. Also, double tapping forward should set the player into a sprint.

As it sits now, I don't recommend it. However, I'm sure the game will change for the most part and most of these cons will be irrelevant in 6 months.

reviewText:
Let me first tell you, this game is good. Quality wise, this game is great. The game looks really good using Unreal Engine 4, and to make it better it is really well optomized. I have a GTX 760 and I get around 60-80 frames per a second.

I would like to say the controls feel snappy and good, but it is hard to really attest that since most of the games servers ar really bad. Most unplayable. At best I can find a really laggy game. The game runs fine client side, and if I'm hosting, but other than that I can't say the server side performence is good. I have tried playing on servers with as low of ping as I can find, but they still don't play very well. (I am in the West Coast US, and I don't know how the game runs in the rest of the world. It could run great there).

This game might be really fun to play on LAN, but I only bought one copy of the game, and I can't see if the performence is good then. I'd either like to see better optimization server side (if possible) or some better official servers in the US (if possible). If either of these can't be possible I'd at least like som bots to play with. The game is good, but for me I am not able to experience it.

reviewText:
Its a great idea, but I don't think it was executed well.  Here are a few things that I feel need to be upgraded.

After playing a few levels, I found I spent most of the time running to the playing field, or waiting for the environment to get to them.  (I.e. rubber ducky bath)  Improving our ability to move farther would be better, for instance, capture little sections, and then when rejoining, you can go back to the last section you were in.  But something to get us into the action sooner.

Who cares what server/game, I just want to play.  Since there doesn't appear to be AI, I have to play multiplayer.  But when I try to join a game, with 15/16 people, they are almost always taken.  I usually have to jump on to something with less than 60% population in order to get on.  Just give me a button to join the next immediate game.  Let the computer figure out what server is available.

80% of the deaths don't feel learnable.  I.e. I died because of being shot by distant player.  The speed and ease of death in the game wouldn't be a problem if would could jump right back in.  but the game makes us wait, and then have to run to anywhere useful.

Edge forgiveness in the bath.  Its hard to tell where the edge is.  It is especially frustrating in the water, where you just fall into the tub and die.  I'd like some forgiveness on it, like if you are slipping off the edge, but then walk/run back right away, then let us get back on the edge.

I'm not suggesting that all my suggestions be taken as sollutions, but I would suggest taking the challenges seriously and come up with some improvement.

reviewText:
This game looked awesome in the trailer, and it looked like it would be a clever throwback to the old Army Men games.

Maybe I was going in expecting a differant type of game than I should have, or maybe I have a bias to particular kinds of shooters.  But here's what I think.

From the video I thought it might be a class based shooter like Team Fortress 2.  Which would have made sense.  I mean army men just have a single built in weapon so the game seemed perfect for that.  Unfortunately that's not the case.  Every player has every gun.

Now that wouldn't be so bad, if health was more meaningful/tankier.  Again by the appearece of the game I expected arcade shooter kind of health, where I could tank a  cartoony amount of bullets before dying.  Instead, just like 3 or 4 bullets from the assault rifle kills you.  Again, made worse by the fact every single person gets a rocket launcher.

The player count is redicoulously low. Just 5 v. 5.  I think the minimum standard these days is 8 v 8, with most games eager to reach rediculous player counts.

This game was a great idea but not executed that well.  If it dropped it's realistic shooter/CoD-like elements and replaced them with arcade shooter/TF2-like ones I think it could be amazing.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game. I'm a huge fan of the Army Men series, and when I stumbled across this I happily put the money down. Once again I was burned. Lately when I buy a multiplayer game on Steam I'm met with just a few conclusions- It's not finished (EA, which is clear at purchase but the state of the games rarely changes), It's got 0 community, or it's got a community based in another region almost entirely/I can't get a good ping in any server and it's not my connection. This game was the latter. I found numerous servers online with lots of players, but every single one was in Europe or another country, and my Ping was well above 200. I found a couple US servers but invariably they were all too high ping, or completely empty. It's a damned shame because this concept was extremely attractive to me. I've been looking for another shooter like Army Men or Toy Soldiers for a very long time. Especially one with today's graphical potential and online play. For such a new game it's really a shame that I had to refund it today. I just can't get by finding one or two games every couple hours like I would have if I'd continued playing.

reviewText: Maps are far too linear. Every time you respawn you get a fresh shot in your missle launcher that is a one hit kill with a bunch of splash damage. 90% of the combat in this game seems to be done with the one hit missle launcher and begins to feel stale very quickly. When you die it forces you to walk all the way across the map to get back to the battle. Normally this wouldn't be an issue to me but when you're constantly walking all the way across a map and getting intantly killed by a rocket launcher it becomes a little bit frustrating. I refunded this game and will consider repurchasing if they update the maps to be bigger and if they rethink their rocket launcher balance.

reviewText:
PROS:
1) Maps looks great
2) Pretty fun once you have a decent team together

CONS: (in it's current state and in no particular order)
1) Too many countdowns (post/pre match), need to get into the action faster instead of listening to kids bicker in chat
2) UI needs to be more intuitive and responsive, green everything doesn't work
3) Maps - too much emphasis on teamwork to gain position, too many choke points that you must run through, team either goes in one by one with the rocket launcher, gets a kill then dies or they sit back and tries to snipe. With most maps, it's only 2 lanes, adding in a 3rd should help.
4) Fishtank map has terrible spawn points. You need to focus on 2-3 low grav jumps (with a chance of dieing) instead of how you're going to attack the enemy.
5) No shooting while jumping. This needs to be fixed but in the right way... I'd probably slow the run/sprint speed down so this doesn't turn into arena shooter.

VERDICT:
This game has tons of potential, the small dev team did a great job however currently there's too many annoyances for any serious replay value. I'll be keeping this on the shelf and checking back in a month or two. Hopefully they address the small issues first then focus on improving the game play.

reviewText:
I hate to say it but this game is pretty bad. This is the first time I completely regret buying a game. I really wanted to like it too since the theme really grabbed my attention, a jolly, fun casual game but there's just so much missing. And the game isn't even early access; it's a complete game that needs work which is disappointing. First of all the matchmaking is ridiculous. There shouldn't be so many complications to simply find a game that you'll play on for only 5 minutes. The hit detection doesn't feel right either, especially if you're used to playing legit shooters; you will not settle for this game. Just keep that in mind. Despite the good reviews which I hoped I would agree with, you will realize how bad the game is if you're used to playing high end or popular games. And keep in mind, the game is boring and on top of that, they didn't implement any reason to come back to the damn thing. No ranking or levels, no unlocks, no challenges, nothing. What gives me any reason to keep playing if it's not fun in the first place.

Add some kind of reward system so the players can put however many wasted hours they played into use. After playing a couple games I gave up; I might go back one day if I'm really bored or want to give it a second try. Until then I'm hoping some improvements are made and then I can possibly enjoy the game. Maybe I didn't give it enough time to grow on me, who knows? Either way I spent $10 (on sale) on a game I am not satisfied with, and it's fine that my money is gone but please don't waste others' as well. Drop it to $5 or less, considering that's the most it's worth. I'm really hoping the developers know there's a ton to change with this game, if they don't realize then it's pretty much going no where.

I suggest you high-expectation players out there pass on this game and allow it to get better even if you have to pay more later on. It has lots of potential but that doesn't change the fact that right now it's horrible. You'll be able to tell within the first few minutes of playing, a sense of just.. disappointment. It's unexplainable but the game does not feel right at all. and for $10... I'm trying not to remind myself...but yea go spend that on a few csgo cases. Peace.

reviewText: Welcome to Server Full" the video game.  The join server button results in nothing but wasted time and a "Server Full" error.  Attempting to actually join a server from the server browser results in "Connection to Host Lost" due to 95% of the servers being in Europe.   I saw two full US servers in the list and the rest were completely empty.  Also the servers are bugged it seems because several say they support 20 players but are still giving you a "Server Full" error at 10 connections.    I'd expect this kind of poor code from an early release title but not from a "full release" game.  I'll update my review when the netcode gets some more polish."

reviewText:
I ended up refunding this game. When you look at it, most of us think back to Army men 3D back in the day, and it brings back so many good memories, but the game itself just didnt satisfy me and I was rather disapointed.

The maps are mode locked:
The bathtub map is CTF locked and the map is so small and simple that you could easily snipe an opponent in their spawn
The fooseball table map is... well fooseball locked and no one seems to like it

I also dont like the dolphin diving, thats always a big no for any game in my book
ex: let me just roll all over the place (slight speed boost when rolling) so you cant hit me and then il just use my shotgun in your face
or the fact that you can jump twice the hight of your character, no speed penalty, spamable.... ect you get the idea.

I know this is a fictional toy soldier game, but I am not a fan of how the game plays so I refunded and threw my money at planetside

reviewText:
Now that I am finally able to join the game after the first few days of launch and the terrible server connection issues there are still major flaws with this game.

First off, hit box detection is terrible.  I mean really bad.  I even went as far as starting games with friends and having them stand still. Aiming right at my friend and firing and not a single hit.  Its bad.  Also with  hit detection there is very little to no visuals when you actuall hit a target, no sounds just a little pulse of your crappy cross hair.

The second major issue is map balance.  Most maps are bascially tug of war style. When one team can push forward, the losing team will usually fail.  Spawn times and points are weird on most maps making half the map you running and running and running while only actually engaged in combat for seconds before you either die or kill off the few enimes.

Visually, the game is fantastic. Along with great sound tracks makes for one of the great pros of the game.

It's not the worse game out there, but needs some polishing work before I would even call this out of beta process yet. Way over priced for what it is.  I wasted  money on a game that should have been considered early access at half the price.  Already tried to play it enough to like it and went over the 2 hour window for a refund which is my fault.

reviewText: CONSTANT server dropping. I spent more time trying to get in a game than I did playing this game. Absolutely unacceptable in 2015 for a multiplayer-only game. When I did get into a match, I found it all to be rather dull and uninspired. Yay, the settings are unique!! That's about the only plus. There's no progression, nothing you can level up, no real incentive for doing well in a match. You get EVERY weapon at the outset with limited ammo and are basically left to smash against the opposing team again and again. Everyone has the same gear you do, there are no classes or specialities. Half the time you don't even know where a death came from. The aiming is clunky and weird, the netcode for this game needs a serious overhaul. If you're interested in playing a wholly generic multiplayer shooter in neat settings (because you're a toy, obviously), then sure, try it out. However, this is not the game for me.

reviewText:
Firstly, if you managed to find this game, or even this review on Steam, I applaud you. Now, out of all my years on Steam this will be my first negative review. What a shocker.

I don't hate this game, or the devs. Not one bit. But the sheer amount of players (literally none btw) is enough to make you want to pass up this game. That is the main reason I am giving the game a negatively based review in the first place. Okay, lets start the review.

This game is dead. I don't want to say it but its dead as a game can get because of the very low ammount of players playing.

Pros:

-Gunplay feels okay.

- Nostalgia.

- Well designed maps. Actually very well designed maps, you feel like you are actually immersed
into a childhood if you will, like you actaully feel in a child like place. Dunno how to describe it, takes you back. Could tie into the nostalgia.

- Pretty good graphics.

Cons:

- Lack of players. Seriously, I bought the game on the 1st or 2nd of January which wasn't even a month after the game released, to find only 7 servers full. I haven't played since then so you can imagine how many players are on now. Also, I just checked as of writing this review and only 75.7% of ALL the players who have bought this have the First Play of the Game" achivement. Its what it sounds like
date:
24.3% of everyone who bought it pretty much haven't even played it.

- Connecting issues. Trying to get into 1 match is like trying to find water in a desert.

- Connection issues. Not the same as connecting issues
recommended: because I wasn't able to stay in 1 game for more than 3 minutes because of `"Lost connection to host" all the time.\n\n-Lack of content. No really

reviewText:
This game has a heart in the right place but I feel like it should be marked early access.

The server browser is currently lacking basic functionality, like the option to sort by ping or player count. Joining a game with the automated placement system will put you in an empty game instead of placing you in a partially full one.

Visual/audio feedback is lacking and you often die with little indication of who or what killed you beyond a name in the kill feed.

With that in mind, the nostalgia of Army Men is strong and I'm gonna revisit this game in a couple months.

reviewText:
What a ♥♥♥♥ game...

The level design is interesting, but done with no regard for balance. There's literally a level where the whole map is tan coloured, and all the tan players have near perfect camoflage.

Gunplay is pretty much the worst I've seen in an FPS. There are maps with 'bouncy' areas, where you never stay on the ground, but you cannot shoot while in mid air. The rifle sprays to the point of uselessness whether you tap once or spray for 50 bullets. This causes you to rely on the sniper, which has only 6 bullets per respawn, or the rocket launcher, which has 1. Both weapons are super strong and hard to play against.

Graphically it's messy, but quite well done once you turn off the sickening motion blur.

In terms of interface there's far too much downtime. There are sometimes rounds of 2 minutes with lobby times of 1 minute in between. Cover height makes no sense, sometimes your character holds the weapon at crotch level, but the height of the cover is about up to your chest. Preventing you from shooting but providing no protection against snipers.

Overall, needs serious work in the gunplay area before I'll consider picking it up. Even free games like the original Ace Of Spades (now Build and Shoot) had better, more skill focused gunplay than this.

1/5 stars in its current state. Worth it for $2, don't pay any more than that.

reviewText: I really want to love this game, Army Men needs to be a thing again and the maps are all quite cool. The graphics are nice and it runs well. I give the devs credit for the creative objectives and gimmicks in each map, such as the foosball map which plays out like a shooter version of Rocket League and the freezer map where you have to use flamethrowers to melt the giant ice block containing your team's T-Rex before the other team can. But the execution is ultimately, and sadly, quite poor. The shooting mechanics are not good, there's bad hit detection and possibly bad netcode that makes killing enemies needlessly unreliable and leads to a lot of questionable deaths and frustration. It just doesn't feel satisfying to play, and that's not good. Perhaps one of the biggest problems for me though is that the maps which I find quite fun and endearing, are unfortunately also far, far too large for the 5v5 player limit. This needs to be bumped up to at least 10v10 badly. There's just too much downtime spent running across the maps, not seeing any enemies, for a fast paced game like this to work. Additionally, and this is perhaps personal preference, I don't like that everyone has every weapon by default instead of picking things up on the map. Ammo for them all is also on a cooldown, so once you use your 1 allocated rocket or 6 sniper rounds, you have to wait. It's an odd mechanic to say the least, though I suppose not necessarily unbalanced. The shotgun seems to be everyone's go to at the moment though because it is ridiculously powerful. Right now, as it stands, I can't really recommend this and I'm currently on the fence about refunding it. $10 isn't much, but I feel it could be better spent elsewhere. I genuinely hope the devs improve the game because I've been waiting for another game like this for the better part of the past 15 years, but until that time, I may just have to get out my N64 and Sarge's Heroes again to get the experience I was hoping to have here.

reviewText:
The Mean Greens REVIEWFULL REVIEW[gonewiththewin.com]

Years of Call of Duties, Ghost Recons, Rainbox Sixes, Halos, and more shooters get washed together after a while. Especially military based ones. Yet Mean Greens parachutes in as a multiplayer online only shooter? With good reason, this is the kind of game to play to get away from other games. It's low price means low risk. It brings with it excellent Unreal 4 based visuals, decent gameplay, and a comedic tone to all its maps that is highly appreciated.

It has its drawbacks which are described in the full review linked above, but in short spurts Mean Greens is a fun off-beat game that's worth a look, especially if you are a fan of shooters.

reviewText:
The minute I saw the gameplay footage, I just knew I had to play this game. After about 10 minutes of fumbling around for a server (there are serverside issues), I finally got in a game. And I was in for a treat.

There are 10 maps, each has a unique theme and gamemode. There are 5 weapons, and you start out with all of them when you spawn. The weapons are all unique, from the simple assault rifle to the one shot-kill rocket launcher (which is a bit op). There are no power-ups, no killstreaks, no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Period. Weeeeeelll, except for the rocket launcher, because you get one shot with it per life (unless you survive long enough for its long cooldown to reset), and so every time you respawn you get a shot. Often gameplay progresses as:

1. Shoot someone with the rocket launcher

2. Someone shoots you with the rocket launcher

3. Respawn and get another rocket launcher shot

So theres the only balancing issue I see. The only way I can see to fix this is to make the Rocket Launcher a powerup or killstreak bonus, or some other way.
EDIT: They nerfed the rocket launcher- cooldown now carries over between deaths. This is a noticeable improvement. Thanks devs.

Additionally, there are some gamemodes where it is impossible for either side to score, and 90% of the time it ends in a tie. Those maps are Kitchen Run and Barnyard Ball.

In Kitchen Run, neither side can make it to the cup because the map is so linear. I'm thinking you should add some more paths through the donuts at the midway point to mix things up, because the donut area is just a huge bloodbath where very few make it past. Let alone do any players make it past the stove or sink.

It is so hard to score in Barnyard Ball because the ball always ends up on the edges where the flippers aren't, and the ball always gets stuck in the corner. I'd suggest making the edges and corners of the table at a slight incline to keep the ball somewhat closer to the middle area where the flippers are.

Also, there is NO progression system. I am opposed to unlockable combat bonuses, but here is my simple idea for progression:

It would kind of work like Rocket League, in that you get a random cosmetic after every fully completed game. There could be categories of unlockables, like hats, gun skins, and backpack" style items.

Hats would be monochromatic to match your team color.
Gun skins would be patterned
date: like tiger stripes or camo.\nBackpack items would be small real-world items
recommended: like paper clips or pencil-top erasers. Maybe even those little toothpick flags you get in martinis.\n\nThose are just my ideas. This game has so much potential
hoursPlayed: and the devs currently have a fairly big audience
voteText: but I don't want to see this game die like Titanfall and so many other games have. You guys have a captive audience
helpfulPercent: now keep us entertained! :3"

reviewText:
This is childhood nostalgia in the making.

PROS ABOUT THE GAME.

If you're a huge fan of the ORIGINAL Star Wars Battlefront, SOCOM, and of course....Army Men, then this game is your personal porn stash of glory. Using the unreal engine, this awesome game of plastic green vs tan toy soldiers is beyond expectations. It does not involve any kind of ranking system to unlock anything, nor does it include pay to win options. All weapons are available and is a jump in and jump out of based games. This game is a rare jewel among the pile of coal for video games and if you need that awesome replayable value of a game, then this is the choice. I will definitely be listing this game as one of my top 10 choices of 2015.
(Cons listed below)

PROS
- Beautiful Maps
- Smooth Animation
- Awesome Music
- Replayable Value


CONS ABOUT THE GAME

Certain suggestions for the game I would recommend is additional animations for the army men. RPG's blow up the soldiers into bits which is cool. However, it would be amazing if the fire from flame-throwers could melt you, or have bullets and pellets from rifles and shotguns blow chunks off of your character to show a more cool reaction from shooting/fighting. Dodging animation into walls/objects sometimes have clipping issues and camera glitches where your camera is forced into different directions. Another issue that is a bit unsettling is random loud audio popping noises that happen throughout the game. Makes it a bit unsettling for the ears. Also, another suggestion would be for the RPG's. They do not cause self-inflicted damage like grenades do when shooting at an opponent at point blank range. Although it has a cool down timer per use, it allows a disadvantage for an opponent to run into the middle of a squad to shoot the ground and kill everyone except himself. Other than that though, this game is epicly amazing.

CONS
- Loud Popping Noises With Audio Randomly Throughout Matches
- Dodge Animation Sometimes Has Clipping and Forced Camera Moving Errors.
- AOE Self-Inflicted Damage Should be Applied to RPG's.
- Needs more dynamic deaths for your character models depending on weapons.

Anyways, i'll be playing this more on my show for Twitch. Check out the live broadcasts here :D.

Check out live gameplay on my twitch --- www.twitch.tv/tekavor

reviewText:
Let me start by saying if you loved playing Army Sarge's heroes on N64 and wanted a spin off multiplayer third person shooter than buy this game!

Pros-

-The graphics are astounding! Seriously the best I have seen from Unreal engine 4 so far.
-Multiple beautiful maps which truly make you feel like a tiny plastic soldier.
-Many different unique gamemodes which allow fun filled action to ensue throughout various hours of gameplay.
-No class system, rather all players have access to 5 different guns which represent various ways to play (all need to be used situationally).

Cons-

-16 player max server (understandable fighting within game is already chaotic).
-Animation can at times seem buggy, hopefully this will improve throughout being updated.
-No Autobalance which in effect allows the team with the most amount of players to obtain a very large advantage (especially since maps are at most 8v8)
-Not much other than multiplayer modes.

All in all this game is definetly worth a purchase. A very unique third-person shooter that entails endless hours of fun!

reviewText:
The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare is a faithful recreation of the Army Men games we all know and love, especially an emphasis on the multi-player chaos of Sarge's Heroes 1 and 2. The game consists of (currently) 10 maps each with it's own unique gamemode. One map may be a simple TDM while another could be CTF. Each map really emits a feeling of tininess as you wage war in a bathtub or on a mini-train. The map design is simply excellent.

The gameplay however, is not as great as the map design and overall aesthetic of the game. It's a generic third-person shooter. The shooting in particular isn't impactful or sound all that great. Every player oddly has access to every weapon in the game. 5 in total, M16, Shotgun, (overpowered) Sniper, Bazooka, and a grenade. Why the devs didn't instead go for a class based system is beyond me.

Final Thoughts: Incredibly fun although very simplistic depending on what mode you're playing. The devs have confirmed vehicles and new maps coming soon and a possible splitscreen and singeplayer campaign.

Concerns: Shotgun is OP, can insta-kill from a few feet if you're lucky. Jumping and rolling should cost stamina. Classes should be added so that every player isn't the exact same. Train map should be ticket based, not who can zerg the higher cap the fastest before the game ends. And that's about it. Great game, I reccommend due to nostalgia and the promises they told us and said they will implement (Vehicles, larger maps,etc. I doubt you would like this game if you aren't a fan of the Army men series.

reviewText: This heavily reminds me of the Army Men series more so than I anticipated. It may be lacking content in some places and has its bugs, but that doesn't stop it from being a fantastic game to play, especially with friends. Between its bombastic live scoring, unique level concepts, high quality visuals, and overall fun gameplay. I'd say this is a worthy spiritual successor to the greatness of the Army Men games. It may not be the greatest thing ever, but if you can look past some of its short comings you'll find a game that has a lot of heart and soul put into it. With the devs working hard on putting out patches and more content, 10-15 dollars is a very good bargain. Of course, it helps to play with friends, but it's not necessary. It's fun to play period. Give it a shot, you will be pleasantly surprised.

reviewText: I really hate to give this game a thumbs down. I really do. But as of this writing the game simply feels unbalanced and a little rough. The game is gorgeous, exciting, and very promising however. It is sorely lacking a local splitscreen or bot mode. I kind of wanted to just sort of drop in on a game and play casually for an hour or so...but no. That doesn't happen in this game. Newcomers in this game get SLAUGHTERED. The rocket launcher is completely OP and such a cheap kill that it just feels unsatisfying. Meanwhile the flamethrower I'm convinced actually does nothing. The grenade physics are extremely dodgy. I always felt like I was kinda dropping a grenade in a general direction instead of actually throwing it. the join game" option on the main menu is completely broken. reviewText: This is a fun game. It brings back memories of the old N64 days of melting the tan. The maps are fantastic, the balancing weapons/updating is incredibly frequent, and the objectives for the different maps can provide game play that is completely unique to the arena that you are currently playing on. It looks great, plays great, and you can tell a lot of work was put into the game.\nHOWEVER. There is no community for this game. There are never more than 5 or 10 people playing at one time, and this is at the absolute peak. When the game first came out there were plenty of people playing. Slowly, people have just stopped playing the game. This leads to some horribly frustrating moments when you want to play this game, but are forced to play with 3 people or don't play at all. This is a STRICTLY online game and I can't even play the game with a full match of 9 other people. This speaks volumes about the difficulties that the devs have had with their servers. If staying connected in a match wasn't difficult enough, sometimes the game doesn't show ANY SERVERS AT ALL. I would naturally assume this was my fault, some error in my steam or my online connection. No. This is an issue that the devs seem to be completely ignoring. This could be a beautiful, fun game that I could spend countless hours on. As of this moment however, this game makes me wish that I could get my ten dollars back. I'm not sure how its proper to pay for something that you can't even use. 4/10. Loved it at first, now just wishing I had kept the 10 dollars in my pocket.

reviewText:
The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare is a by-the-book, pure multiplayer third person shooter by developer Virtual Basement. The players assume the role of plastic toy soldiers as they try to clear different objectives across different maps taking place in different rooms of the same house (like the kitchen or the bathroom). Each of the ten maps the game is shipped with host a dedicate game mode that requires the two team to pursue a single objective while they try to kill each other: while some are derived from your typical multiplayer shooters, like capture the flag or control point capture, others are more unique and are about manipulating the level's assets in a certain way to achieve victory.
The Mean Greens could however really use a loadout/inventory feature for the players: as it stands, each soldier comes into play with the same five weapons (an assault rifle, a bazooka, a sniper rifle, a shotgun and a flamethrower). On top of not allowing the player to personalize his/her arsenal to fit his/her own playstyle, the stock loadout basically forces everyone to stick with the most powerful weapon for that specific patch cycle and pretty much nothing else.
Another issue that plagues this game as this review's writing is the extremely low number of players worldwide: while finding a match isn't impossible per se, having a series of maps with one team (or both) missing some players is something that happens fairly often.
The strongest suit of The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare remains its presentation: the design of the single maps is always very inspired and plesant to look at and explore as you maul other players, and the soundtrack, on top of fitting the general mood of the game well, is remarkably good for an indie game. If all of the above is worth a purchase is honestly up to you

reviewText:
The Mean Greens REVIEWFULL REVIEW[gonewiththewin.com]

Years of Call of Duties, Ghost Recons, Rainbox Sixes, Halos, and more shooters get washed together after a while. Especially military based ones. Yet Mean Greens parachutes in as a multiplayer online only shooter? With good reason, this is the kind of game to play to get away from other games. It's low price means low risk. It brings with it excellent Unreal 4 based visuals, decent gameplay, and a comedic tone to all its maps that is highly appreciated.

It has its drawbacks which are described in the full review linked above, but in short spurts Mean Greens is a fun off-beat game that's worth a look, especially if you are a fan of shooters.

reviewText:
This is childhood nostalgia in the making.

PROS ABOUT THE GAME.

If you're a huge fan of the ORIGINAL Star Wars Battlefront, SOCOM, and of course....Army Men, then this game is your personal porn stash of glory. Using the unreal engine, this awesome game of plastic green vs tan toy soldiers is beyond expectations. It does not involve any kind of ranking system to unlock anything, nor does it include pay to win options. All weapons are available and is a jump in and jump out of based games. This game is a rare jewel among the pile of coal for video games and if you need that awesome replayable value of a game, then this is the choice. I will definitely be listing this game as one of my top 10 choices of 2015.
(Cons listed below)

PROS
- Beautiful Maps
- Smooth Animation
- Awesome Music
- Replayable Value


CONS ABOUT THE GAME

Certain suggestions for the game I would recommend is additional animations for the army men. RPG's blow up the soldiers into bits which is cool. However, it would be amazing if the fire from flame-throwers could melt you, or have bullets and pellets from rifles and shotguns blow chunks off of your character to show a more cool reaction from shooting/fighting. Dodging animation into walls/objects sometimes have clipping issues and camera glitches where your camera is forced into different directions. Another issue that is a bit unsettling is random loud audio popping noises that happen throughout the game. Makes it a bit unsettling for the ears. Also, another suggestion would be for the RPG's. They do not cause self-inflicted damage like grenades do when shooting at an opponent at point blank range. Although it has a cool down timer per use, it allows a disadvantage for an opponent to run into the middle of a squad to shoot the ground and kill everyone except himself. Other than that though, this game is epicly amazing.

CONS
- Loud Popping Noises With Audio Randomly Throughout Matches
- Dodge Animation Sometimes Has Clipping and Forced Camera Moving Errors.
- AOE Self-Inflicted Damage Should be Applied to RPG's.
- Needs more dynamic deaths for your character models depending on weapons.

Anyways, i'll be playing this more on my show for Twitch. Check out the live broadcasts here :D.

Check out live gameplay on my twitch --- www.twitch.tv/tekavor

reviewText:
More Reviews @ TheVideogameBacklog.com

So here we are with another FPS game to hit Steam. The Mean Greens will throw you for a loop, though, if you think it will just be another grey/brown/green romp through a shiny explosion-fest. The Mean Greens goes at the genre through a different set of windows. It decides to bust through the fun windows. You know the ones that haven’t really been broken recently. Everyone is all up on the hyper-realistic shooters and while a lot of them are pretty stinking cool, they all kind of merge together in my brain at least. In The Mean Greens you play as green or tan army men straight out of your childhood… if you were raised with them instead of an iPad. I know some of you may only be familiar with them thanks to Toy Story… and I’m mostly ok with that.

I’m going to go with what I didn’t like first since that’s a shorter list and everyone always likes to know what they are getting into before they jump into the pool. The shooting is the only thing that troubles me here. For the most part, my friends and I have noticed a bit of a discrepancy between our aim and some of the other players. I’m fairly sure everyone at this point is on the up and up so that leaves me with a few options. Either other people have just acclimated to the spread of the guns better than some or using a controller has some added benefits over the mouse and keyboard option. Some people can just wreck with the regular machine gun while I tend to struggle with it and the shotgun (although most of my kills are with the machine gun). I’m pretty good with the rocket launcher, but that’s like being proud to win with a gun at a knife fight. I may figure it out eventually, but something does feel off about the controls.

On the bright side, with good teamwork, shooting isn’t everything. The Mean Greens is set up as more of an objective based game. I tend to only stick with maps that are not free-for-all based. Luckily that leaves me with… every other map in the pool other than Art Table Shuffle. What that means is you’re left with:

-playing capture the flag in a fish aquarium
-attacking and defending plates of cookies on a toy train driving around a Christmas tree
-playing fußball on a barn themed fußball table
-trying to unfreeze your dinosaur in a freezer before the other team can free theirs
-even more, but I don’t like doing lists like this, go play the game

This game has given so many different takes on similar themes that it just makes my heart happy. Even with dying at times, I’ve found myself having a laugh at the hilarity of the situation my team of toy soldiers have found themselves in. Some of that is in part to learning how the levels are composed and where everything is. Most of it is due to the crazy atmosphere and great music. Ever wanted to assault or defend a birthday cake? Well, The Mean Greens gives you that chance!

I guess I can throw out one last thing. There has been a lot of complaining about servers and being kicked and all that jazz. Yes, I do get kicked automatically from servers at times. Yes, that does suck. Does it happen a lot? No, not really once you find a server. Finding a server would be another complaint if you want to use the “find server” option. They said they’ve patched it, but as of yesterday, it will usually put me into a server all by myself instead of one with room. Yes, that’s unfortunate, but I can just as easily go to the server list and order it by ping and click into a server and Bob’s your uncle. It’s not ideal, but it’s not a deal breaker. Let’s stop being spoiled here. If that’s your only complaint, I’d say be thankful.

Score: Gewd/Tasty

I will reiterate what I said in my tweet in that I believe that The Mean Greens is the “best variation on gameplay in the FPS genre in the long time including Splatoon.” That is not to say that it is without its faults and when they hit you, you notice them. However, it is super nice to see a developer go and create a game in a familiar genre and not simply rehash what is already available in so many different forms already. There are a lot of shooters out there that will run you a bit of money and there are a lot of free ones as well that don’t suck. At the end of the day, a lot of them are simply the same game with a different color of paint. So much is different in The Mean Greens and anyone who even likes to dabble in the FPS genre would be a fool to not try The Mean Greens out. It’s simply way to fun to avoid.

reviewText:
The minute I saw the gameplay footage, I just knew I had to play this game. After about 10 minutes of fumbling around for a server (there are serverside issues), I finally got in a game. And I was in for a treat.

There are 10 maps, each has a unique theme and gamemode. There are 5 weapons, and you start out with all of them when you spawn. The weapons are all unique, from the simple assault rifle to the one shot-kill rocket launcher (which is a bit op). There are no power-ups, no killstreaks, no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Period. Weeeeeelll, except for the rocket launcher, because you get one shot with it per life (unless you survive long enough for its long cooldown to reset), and so every time you respawn you get a shot. Often gameplay progresses as:

1. Shoot someone with the rocket launcher

2. Someone shoots you with the rocket launcher

3. Respawn and get another rocket launcher shot

So theres the only balancing issue I see. The only way I can see to fix this is to make the Rocket Launcher a powerup or killstreak bonus, or some other way.
EDIT: They nerfed the rocket launcher- cooldown now carries over between deaths. This is a noticeable improvement. Thanks devs.

Additionally, there are some gamemodes where it is impossible for either side to score, and 90% of the time it ends in a tie. Those maps are Kitchen Run and Barnyard Ball.

In Kitchen Run, neither side can make it to the cup because the map is so linear. I'm thinking you should add some more paths through the donuts at the midway point to mix things up, because the donut area is just a huge bloodbath where very few make it past. Let alone do any players make it past the stove or sink.

It is so hard to score in Barnyard Ball because the ball always ends up on the edges where the flippers aren't, and the ball always gets stuck in the corner. I'd suggest making the edges and corners of the table at a slight incline to keep the ball somewhat closer to the middle area where the flippers are.

Also, there is NO progression system. I am opposed to unlockable combat bonuses, but here is my simple idea for progression:

It would kind of work like Rocket League, in that you get a random cosmetic after every fully completed game. There could be categories of unlockables, like hats, gun skins, and backpack" style items.

Hats would be monochromatic to match your team color.
Gun skins would be patterned
date: like tiger stripes or camo.\nBackpack items would be small real-world items
recommended: like paper clips or pencil-top erasers. Maybe even those little toothpick flags you get in martinis.\n\nThose are just my ideas. This game has so much potential
hoursPlayed: and the devs currently have a fairly big audience
voteText: but I don't want to see this game die like Titanfall and so many other games have. You guys have a captive audience
helpfulPercent: now keep us entertained! :3"

reviewText:
A decently polished, third-person shooter with map-specific gamemodes. I like the look and the sounds/music plus the idea of each map having it's own objective is cool. Some maps need a bit of tuning, as most games end up a draw on a few of them due to it taking FOREVER to reach the objective (one linear path to get to the other side and once you die, you start all over at the beginning). Voice chat would be nice (I think it's still missing as of me typing this) and lag has been an issue a couple of times (but mostly lag free, for me at least). Yes, there is a nostalgia factor if you played the old 3DO Army Men titles and that does play a small part in why I bought this in the first place, but the game is good in its own right. I think this game is in need of minimal tuning and additional content, and I think this will happen seeing how active the devs have been thus far.

tl;dr

7.5/10 Decent Third-Person Shooter with surprising polish for an Early Access Title, just needs a bit... more"."

reviewText: It's great fun. There is a bit of weird latency sometimes, not sure if it's the net code or the 3rd party servers, or if it's the peer to peer user games that I'm joining. (The official servers are dedicated but you can easily start a peer to peer match yourself in the menu) I have no problem joining games, just use the server browser (you may see high pings but once you're in they go down severely). There are 10 maps, each plays as it's own game type. There's the basic TDM, FFA, KOTH, CTF, Neutral CTF, capture points, but some maps have their own completly unique game types that fit the toy soldier environment such as an attack/defen map where you have to light birthday candles with your flamethrower, or thaw out your dinosaur in the freezer before the other team thaws theirs.

reviewText: In its current state, The Mean Greens is a visually appealing (and nostalgic) 3rd person shooting game full of immense potential, but it currently falls short of providing a full and entertaining game experience. What looks like a fun trip through toy laden war grounds quickly looses its luster with the lack of proper visceral feedback, a cute but quickly annoying theme song (as it is the ONLY music in the game and is audible everywhere), an infuriating respawn system, and it is all enveloped by a clunky and rough UI. Overall, this game has a lot of potential, but as it currently stands, it feels more like an Early Access title where the attention was focus on level design.

reviewText:
This game has great potential as a shooter. The map variety is amazing and unlike any shooter I have played before.

Pros:

1. Every map has a unique game mode and environment
2. It feels like a modern shooter so the movement and actions are pretty fluid

Cons:

1. The hit box when shooting feels way off

2. When switching weapons it takes a good 2-3 seconds before the weapon you selected becomes equipped. If you try to shoot or aim before your character physically equips it you will stick to the weapon you currently had equipped which makes it frustrating and slows down the pace of the game

3. Nerf the rocket launcher or at least make it to where you can have loadouts and only 2 weapons per loadout (1 loadout per match). Honestly everyone just spams rocket launchers and it becomes the same thing over and over and over

4. Sometimes the controls don't work (for example when I click the aim button but it doesn't do anything, or try to shoot someone and nothing comes out even though I have a full clip).

5. Obvious connect to host/server issues, don't need to explain here


Overall this game deserves to be up there with the top shooters, it is so unique and fun and has the potential to be competitive. I understand this game only came out 6 days ago which is why I know they can fix/patch things to make this great game into a fantastic game.

Definitely a buy

reviewText: This heavily reminds me of the Army Men series more so than I anticipated. It may be lacking content in some places and has its bugs, but that doesn't stop it from being a fantastic game to play, especially with friends. Between its bombastic live scoring, unique level concepts, high quality visuals, and overall fun gameplay. I'd say this is a worthy spiritual successor to the greatness of the Army Men games. It may not be the greatest thing ever, but if you can look past some of its short comings you'll find a game that has a lot of heart and soul put into it. With the devs working hard on putting out patches and more content, 10-15 dollars is a very good bargain. Of course, it helps to play with friends, but it's not necessary. It's fun to play period. Give it a shot, you will be pleasantly surprised.

reviewText: I really hate to give this game a thumbs down. I really do. But as of this writing the game simply feels unbalanced and a little rough. The game is gorgeous, exciting, and very promising however. It is sorely lacking a local splitscreen or bot mode. I kind of wanted to just sort of drop in on a game and play casually for an hour or so...but no. That doesn't happen in this game. Newcomers in this game get SLAUGHTERED. The rocket launcher is completely OP and such a cheap kill that it just feels unsatisfying. Meanwhile the flamethrower I'm convinced actually does nothing. The grenade physics are extremely dodgy. reviewText:
This game has great potential as a shooter. The map variety is amazing and unlike any shooter I have played before.

Pros:

1. Every map has a unique game mode and environment
2. It feels like a modern shooter so the movement and actions are pretty fluid

Cons:

1. The hit box when shooting feels way off

2. When switching weapons it takes a good 2-3 seconds before the weapon you selected becomes equipped. If you try to shoot or aim before your character physically equips it you will stick to the weapon you currently had equipped which makes it frustrating and slows down the pace of the game

3. Nerf the rocket launcher or at least make it to where you can have loadouts and only 2 weapons per loadout (1 loadout per match). Honestly everyone just spams rocket launchers and it becomes the same thing over and over and over

4. Sometimes the controls don't work (for example when I click the aim button but it doesn't do anything, or try to shoot someone and nothing comes out even though I have a full clip).

5. Obvious connect to host/server issues, don't need to explain here


Overall this game deserves to be up there with the top shooters, it is so unique and fun and has the potential to be competitive. I understand this game only came out 6 days ago which is why I know they can fix/patch things to make this great game into a fantastic game.

Definitely a buy

reviewText:
The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare is a by-the-book, pure multiplayer third person shooter by developer Virtual Basement. The players assume the role of plastic toy soldiers as they try to clear different objectives across different maps taking place in different rooms of the same house (like the kitchen or the bathroom). Each of the ten maps the game is shipped with host a dedicate game mode that requires the two team to pursue a single objective while they try to kill each other: while some are derived from your typical multiplayer shooters, like capture the flag or control point capture, others are more unique and are about manipulating the level's assets in a certain way to achieve victory.
The Mean Greens could however really use a loadout/inventory feature for the players: as it stands, each soldier comes into play with the same five weapons (an assault rifle, a bazooka, a sniper rifle, a shotgun and a flamethrower). On top of not allowing the player to personalize his/her arsenal to fit his/her own playstyle, the stock loadout basically forces everyone to stick with the most powerful weapon for that specific patch cycle and pretty much nothing else.
Another issue that plagues this game as this review's writing is the extremely low number of players worldwide: while finding a match isn't impossible per se, having a series of maps with one team (or both) missing some players is something that happens fairly often.
The strongest suit of The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare remains its presentation: the design of the single maps is always very inspired and plesant to look at and explore as you maul other players, and the soundtrack, on top of fitting the general mood of the game well, is remarkably good for an indie game. If all of the above is worth a purchase is honestly up to you

reviewText: One of the best casual shooters out there with very responsive hitboxes. Whether you storm in alone or in a squad, you feel good. The Mean Greens incorporates 5 different weapons: Assault rifle, Sniper, Shotgun, Rocket Launcher, and Flamethrower. I found myself using each one depending on the range and situation, making for an interesting fight when coupled with combat rolls and varying obstacles. Each level is beautifully designed and unique with fitting and engaging music that fits the atmosphere and brings out its luster. If you are a fan of capturing objectives and teamwork then pick a copy up. On sale it's only $12, you could do a lot worse.
